articles.headline: Obama Calls for Curbs on Offshore Tax Havens
articles.snippet: The proposed tax overhaul, aimed at benefits enjoyed by those harboring cash in offshore accounts, could help raise $210 billion, the administration estimates.
articles.abstract: The proposed tax overhaul, aimed at benefits enjoyed by those harboring cash in offshore accounts, could help raise $210 billion, the administration estimates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday called for curbing offshore tax havens and corporate tax breaks to collect billions of dollars more from multinational companies and wealthy individuals.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Board Ties at Apple and Google Are Scrutinized
articles.snippet: The two companies share two directors, and several people briefed on the Federal Trade Commission inquiry say the agency is studying whether this is an antitrust violation.
articles.abstract: The two companies share two directors, and several people briefed on the Federal Trade Commission inquiry say the agency is studying whether this is an antitrust violation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The Federal Trade Commission has begun an inquiry into whether the close ties between the boards of two of technology’s most prominent companies, Apple and Google, amount to a violation of antitrust laws, according to several people briefed on the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Porous Pakistani Border Could Hinder U.S.
articles.snippet: Afghan militants are able to cross the border with ease, according to interviews with a Taliban logistics tactician.
articles.abstract: Afghan militants are able to cross the border with ease, according to interviews with a Taliban logistics tactician.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  President Obama is pouring more than 20,000 new troops into Afghanistan this year for a fighting season that the United States military has called a make-or-break test of the allied campaign in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: India, Suddenly Starved for Investment
articles.snippet: India’s phenomenal growth in recent years was largely financed by foreign investments and loans, which have fallen sharply in the downturn.
articles.abstract: India’s phenomenal growth in recent years was largely financed by foreign investments and loans, which have fallen sharply in the downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — Sumit Sapra is a member of that ambitious, impatient generation of young Indians who rode the crest of the global economy. In five years, he changed jobs three times, quadrupling his salary along the way. Even when satisfied with his position, he kept his résumé posted on job sites, in case better offers came along. And he splurged. In three years, he bought three cars, moving up a notch in luxury each time. For weekend jaunts, he bought a motorcycle.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Chrysler and Fiat Have Hopes for Happy Relationship
articles.snippet: Many automotive mergers and alliances have done poorly but Fiat is determined not to let that happen in its link with Chrysler.
articles.abstract: Many automotive mergers and alliances have done poorly but Fiat is determined not to let that happen in its link with Chrysler.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  When Daimler-Benz merged with Chrysler in 1998, their leaders told the world to “expect the extraordinary” from the German-American auto giant.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: A Back to Basics Weekend With Warren Buffett
articles.snippet: At Berkshire Hathaway’s meeting, the investor served up advice that was too commonly ignored before the credit crisis.
articles.abstract: At Berkshire Hathaway’s meeting, the investor served up advice that was too commonly ignored before the credit crisis.

articles.headline: Where Home Prices Crashed Early, Signs of a Rebound
articles.snippet: In areas hardest hit by the housing crisis, like Sacramento, and parts of Florida and Nevada, more robust markets suggest the housing sector may be in the early stages of recovery.
articles.abstract: In areas hardest hit by the housing crisis, like Sacramento, and parts of Florida and Nevada, more robust markets suggest the housing sector may be in the early stages of recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO  Is this what a bottom looks like?

articles.headline: G.O.P. Résumé, Cabinet Post, Knack for Odd Jobs
articles.snippet: Ray LaHood’s title is secretary of transportation, but he functions as an ambassador to Capitol Hill Republicans.
articles.abstract: Ray LaHood’s title is secretary of transportation, but he functions as an ambassador to Capitol Hill Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ray LaHood, the secretary of transportation, is not one to toot his own horn over how much he knows about planes, trains and automobile bailouts. On the contrary.
